Modify stack ID lookup to only use stacks:lookup

Currently when we lookup a stack ID (fully qualified name/id) via
stacks:lookup, we also follow the redirect to stacks:show, which
is not allowed for stack users.  We don't actually need to follow
the redirect, as we already have the required ID, so instead we
return the redirect response, so we can just allow all users to

allowed for stack users, e.g resource:signal without having to know

subject: Reverting default keystone API to v2.0
commit_message:
Reverting default keystone API to v2.0

Although keystone v2 has been deprecated, no services use v3 for
authorization. So passing a v3 token_id to other services results
in authorization errors. If the user logs into a domain other than
"default" the user see only unauthorized errors. Currently, when
logging into the "default" domain these authorization errors do not
occur merely because of a bug in keystone that does not validate
the token version. This will likely change some time in the
non-distant future.

Setting the keystone API version to v2.0 is the safest path for now.

Not doing a full revert because the rest of the fixes the previous
patch were valid and required.

subject: Allow pre-1970 dates in If-[Un]Modified-Since
commit_message:
Allow pre-1970 dates in If-[Un]Modified-Since

If I want to fetch an object only if it is newer than the first moon
landing, I send a GET request with header:

    If-Modified-Since: Sun, 20 Jul 1969 20:18:00 UTC

Since that date is older than Swift, I expect a 2xx response. However,
I get a 412, which isn't even a valid thing to do for
If-Modified-Since; it should either be 2xx or 304. This is because of
two problems:

(a) Swift treats pre-1970 dates as invalid, and

(b) Swift returns 412 when a date is invalid instead of ignoring it.

This commit makes it so any time between datetime.datetime.min and
datetime.datetime.max is an acceptable value for If-Modified-Since and
If-Unmodified-Since. Dates outside that date range are treated as
invalid headers and thus are ignored, as RFC 2616 section 14.28
requires ("If the specified date is invalid, the header is ignored").

This only works for dates that the Python standard library can parse,
which on my machine is 01 Jan 1 to 31 Dec 9999. Eliminating those
restrictions would require implementing our own date parsing and
comparison, and that's almost certainly not worth it.

Change-Id: I4cb4903c4e5e3b6b3c9506c2cabbfbda62e82f35

subject: Convert keyring password to str before pickle.loads()
commit_message:
Convert keyring password to str before pickle.loads()

The --os-cache option on Mac OS is broken and you get the
following log message as it's trying to unpickle the auth_ref
fetched from the keyring. The auth token and service catalog
ends up being fetched every time.

WARNING:keystoneclient.httpclient:Unable to retrieve token from keyring __import__() argument 1 must be string without null bytes, not str

The fix is to whack a str() around the result of keyring.get_password()
which fixes the problem but makes me want to tear my hair out
as it's the wrong way to fix it. If you dive into the OS X
backend for the keyring module (https://bitbucket.org/kang/python-keyring-lib/src/598488b60d2148d4c44e64e9e725cde93a258c75/keyring/backends/OS_X.py?at=default) it does the following awful thing:

    # it's a weird hex password, decode it.
    return unicode_str(binascii.unhexlify(hex), 'utf-8')

UTF-8 is not a suitable encoding for possible binary data - the
keyring module assumes that a "password" is something that's a
string which IMHO is why this conversion is being performed.

According to the pickle docs, "By default, the pickle data format
uses a printable ASCII representation. This is slightly more
voluminous than a binary representation. The big advantage of
using printable ASCII (and of some other characteristics of pickle's
representation) is that for debugging or recovery purposes it
is possible for a human to read the pickled file with a standard
text editor." I guess this means that doing a str() on the result
of pickle.loads() will not cause any problems since there will be
no multi-byte sequences in the string.

Change-Id: I897e0f41aa2848fb6986aa6b12c1cea9a6c87b0c

commit_message:
Prevent rescheduling on block device failure

Due to a race condition - it is possible for more instances to race for
the same volume. In such a scenario, the one that fails will get
rescheduled, and in the process detach the volume of a successful
instance.

subject: Handle inspect containers failures
commit_message:
Handle inspect containers failures

Docker's client.inspect_container method may return None
if a container does not exist. As it is expected to be a
dictionary in several places in the docker driver, TypeErrors
may occur and raise unhandled Exceptions.

In the case of list_instances, this results in an
unhandled race-condition. There, we inspect a container
that existed when we begain assembling the list of instances
from the list of running containers, but containers have
been deleted and are no longer inspectable. This patch
will safely skip including those containers in the response
should their inspect_containers call return False.

Furthermore, as it is presumed the return of inspect_container will
be a dictionary, we change the result of a failed query into
an empty dictionary. This will allow successful .get() methods
for easier management of failed queries while still providing
a negative boolean response from the method ({} is False).

subject: Prevent attach volume race when compute is down
commit_message:
Prevent attach volume race when compute is down

As described in the linked bug, if the compute service is down, and
there is a volume attach request, there is a window where
reserve_block_device rpc message may stay on the message bus, which can
cause inconsistent behaviour.

This patch introduces 2 changes that will mitigate this. The first one
is that we will check if the compute service where the instance is
running is up, and if not we will fail the request. This is a
reasonable thing to do since we cannot possibly complete the attach
request at such time and it is better to let the user know that
what he is expecting to happen cannot happen at this time. Since some
attach requests can now return a 503 HTTP status this commit will have

DocImpact

In addition, the EC2 API will now respond with an InternalError.

The second change is that we move the volume reservation before the
reserve_block_device call. This will result in volume being kept in
"attaching" state until the request completes, thus making the window
where volume can be mistaken for available while we are waiting for a
delayed RPC call much smaller.

Closes-bug: #1180040

commit_message:
improve rally output (exception part)

This patch does a lot of trivial changes. But all changes belong to two
things.

The first thing is to make clear that when we could put traceback in rally
output. There is a strategy:

----------------------------------------
|  err type    |  [0]  |  [1]  |  [2]  |
| normal mode  |   N   |   N   |   N   |
| verbose mode |   N   |   N*  |   Y   |
|  debug mode  |   N   |   Y   |   Y   |
----------------------------------------

Why need the [1] between [0] and [2]? The reason is that OpenStack APIs
always return something hard to explain[3]. In another word, we need some
*hacking* for it in rally codes. At least we have to parse it in a way
different with [0] and [2].

The second thing is improving error message so that we could understand
output better. An easy example is that when updating resource status,
the old output always said "resource is in ERROR status". Who is it?
What's the reason for it? This is what this patch is trying to tell you.

Firstly some exception message is improved:

GetResourceFailture: telling users *which resource* failed and *why*

GetResourceErrorStatus: telling users *which resource* is in a *error

And print fault message of nova servers.

subject: Add container forwarding support to updater daemon
commit_message:
Add container forwarding support to updater daemon

This is one of a set of patches implementing a container-forwarding feature.
(see https://blueprints.launchpad.net/swift/+spec/cluster-federation)

Normally the updater daemon digs info out of a container DB and
PUTs it to all the account servers for the container's account.

In the case of a forwarded container the home container simply
contains a reference to a target container on another cluster
and so has 0 objects and 0 bytes itself. Updating the account
servers with 0,0 is not very useful...

So the updater daemons that runs on the home cluster and the target
cluster need to be changed to either, in the case of a home cluster,
fetch the container info from the target cluster and update the
account servers with that, or in the case of a target cluster, get
info out of the container DB and report it back to the home cluster.

The updater daemon figures out whether it's dealing with a forwarded
container by looking for 'x-container-attr-fwd-*' metadata in the
container DB. If the daemon finds a 'x-container-attr-fwd-dest' key
it's found the home part of a forwarded container and uses the value
of the 'x-container-attr-fwd-dest' key as a URL from which to fetch
info using HEAD. If the daemon finds a 'x-container-attr-fwd-src' key
it's found the target part of a forwarded container and uses the value
of the 'x-container-attr-fwd-src' key as a URL to which it reports
info using POST. [It currently does not use PUT as PUTs are only
enabled if Swift is configured to allow account management]

The reason the updater code has been modified to do both fetch and
report is two-fold:
1. Report is more efficient as reports are only sent if data has
changed.
2. Fetch could be a 'belt-and-braces' tactic to handle the cases
where report is not working. Also fetch is the only way that a missing
target container can be detected and fixed.
Note on any given cluster updater daemons can fetch OR report - they
can not do both.

By default the updater daemon acts as it always has and completely
ignores forwarded containers. To configure it to take account of
forwarded containers it needs to be configured with cf_mode 'report',
'fetch' or 'fetchfix' - the latter is an augmented fetch that cleans
up when a missing target container is detected.
The updater daemon can be configured with separate intervals for
reporting, fetching and fixing (cf_report_interval, cf_fetch_interval
and cf_fetch_fix_missing_interval). Timestamps are written into the
container DB to allow these intervals to be honoured and preserved
across multiple passes of the daemon.

To allow these modifications to work a number of other changes had to
be made:
1. swift/account/server.py translates a POST into a PUT
2. swift/proxy/controllers/account.py makes account POST a
delay_denial OP and calls swift.authorize
3. swift/common/middleware/keystoneauth.py allows the daemon
(via a secret key) to do both HEADs and POSTs
4. swift/container/sync.py is modified to prevent home containers
being sync'd elsewhere - they're empty so it's pointless
5. numerous tests

Change-Id: I95f0d0b90184f4472f70dcead75f1a8c5b789546
Implements: blueprint cluster-federation

commit_message:
Explicity teardown on error in libguestfs setup()

Previously, in the setup method of the libguestfs driver
for Nova's VFS, on an error the handle object was simply
dereferenced (set to None), and then an new error was thrown.
This relied on an implicit close() on the handle being called
by GC.  However, in some cases the setup progresses far enough
that the implicit close is not enough, and leaves an "orphaned"
libguestfs VM.

Now, the teardown() method is called explicitly, which ensures that
no "orphaned" VMs are left around in case of an error.

subject: Deploy VM to SDRS datastore cluster (Phase 1)
commit_message:
Deploy VM to SDRS datastore cluster (Phase 1)

This code change intends to enable the capability of vmware driver
to deploy VM to SDRS enabled datastore cluster.

In order to implement that, two options need to be added to
nova.conf. The first option is 'datastore_cluster_name'. This option
allows the end user to specify the name of datastore cluster
(StoragePod object). The second option is 'use_SDRS'. This is a
boolean option. The end user can use it to specify whether or not to
utilize SDRS to select datastore. This option will have effect, only
if datastore_cluster_name is specified.

The VM image need to be a template in VCenter, so that SDRS will
automatically execute VM provisioning task.

If the image is a template in VCenter, and use_SDRS is false, vmware
driver need to select a datastore and call cloneVM_Task() to deploy
the VM. In this case, if datastore_cluster_name is speicified, it
will have effect to filter the datastores from user defined datastore
cluster.

If the image is a template in VCenter, and use_SDRS is true and
datastore_cluster_name is also speicified, vmware driver will call
RecommendDatastores() to deploy the VM. If SDRS is not fully automated,
ApplyStorageDrsRecommendation_Task() need to be called.

All these code changes will be proposed in two phases. In phase 1, only
selecting datastore from datastore cluster will be implemented. The code
to invoke RecommendDatastores() will be implemented in phase 2.

DocImpact

Add version 2.0 of conductor rpc interface

This commit adds a new major revision to the rpc interface used to
talk to the conductor service.  The old version will be retained in
Icehouse for Havana rolling upgrade capability.  1.x can be dropped
as soon as Juno development opens.

When 1.x gets dropped, we will be able to remove the following methods
from the conductor manager, as well as all other supporting code for
these methods throughout the conductor:

 - ping()
 - instance_get()
 - instance_get_all()
 - migration_get()
 - migration_get_unconfirmed_by_dest_compute()
 - migration_create()
 - migration_update()
 - aggregate_get()

* dhcpv6-stateful
* dhcpv6-stateless
* slaac

In addition to these values, additional behaviors are specified for
when only one of the attributes is set. For example, a Neutron network
that uses a physical router as a gateway, that transmits ICMPv6 Router
Advertisement packets to configure hosts on the network will create
Neutron Subnets that have ipv6_ra_mode *not* set, and ipv6_address_mode
set to 'slaac' so that Neutron will calculate EUI64 addresses for
each port assigned to the subnet, and not spawn a Dnsmasq process.

subject: Add ability to specify IP for service
commit_message:
Add ability to specify IP for service

The problem that this change addresses is that the address_for method
will not work correctly if there are multiple IP address associated
with the specified interface.

The approach to solving this problem and moving towards the overall
goal of having one place where service networking information is
stored is to convert address_for calls into endpoints, and add a
address() method to the endpoints interface for IP address resolution.

The address() method has the following behavior: if the
bind_interface of an endpoint is set, then the IP is looked up on
the interface.  Otherwise, the IP specified in the host attribute is
returned.  This allows the caller to choose either method of
determining what IP a service will be bound to.

This change switches the identity cookbook to use an endpoint for
binding instead of address_for.

This change is dependent on the follow change which adds the endpoint
to common:

existing connections in the pool become invalid. There is no sense to
check every single connection in the pool, as this may take a long
time (e.g. when python-mysqldb driver is used with eventlet green
threads, there is no context switch on db IO, so the whole process is
blocked until socket read times out). Dispose all connections in the
pool when disconnect is detected, they will be recreated on demand
then.
